commit_message:
Take another try to ping instance respecting new MTU size

Sometimes data size in network packets should be lower than
(1500-28) bytes because additional devices, that are used in virtual
network, increase size of the packets so the desired size of the
packet doesn't match actual MTU size allowed for the communication
channel.

Change-Id: I3ba943cd140cde69e4e66062d8690ef5e8b7e7aa
Closes-Bug:#1471317
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/40/198440/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: logger.info("MTU on controller is equal to {0}".format(mtu)) cmd = "ping -M do -q -s {0} -c 7 -w 10 {1}".format(int(mtu) - 28, floating_ip.ip) logger.info("Executing command: {0}".format(cmd)) if res['exit_code'] == 1: # No packets were received at all for l in res['stdout']: if 'Message too long' in l: logger.error("Incorrect MTU: '{0}'".format(l)) m = re.match(".*mtu=(\d+)", l) if m: mtu = m.group(1) cmd = ("ping -M do -q -s {0} -c 7 -w 10 {1}" .format(int(mtu) - 28, floating_ip.ip)) logger.info("Executing command using new MTU: {0}" .format(cmd)) res = remote.execute(cmd) break 'Most packages were dropped, result is {0}'.format(res))
deleted_lines: logger.debug('mtu is equal to {0}'.format(mtu)) cmd = "ping -q -s {0} -c 7 -w 10 {1}".format(int(mtu) - 28, floating_ip.ip) 'most packages were dropped, result is {0}'.format(res))

commit_message:
Fix broken unit tests

Fix following tests:
    admin/shares/tests.py:
        - test_delete_share

    project/shares/shares/tests.py:
        - test_create_share
        - test_create_share_from_snapshot
        - test_delete_share
        - test_create_rule

Remove test_create_share_from_snapshot_URL in
project/shares/shares/tests.py, as Manila does not use
data from URL for creation of a share. This test is invalid left-over.

Closes-Bug: #1472178

commit_message:
Have bootstrap script create the initial endpoint

Due to a few issue that exist between keystone v3 and v2.0 the endpoint
needs to be created as v2.0. If it is created as v3, v2.0 queries will not
see the endpoint.

https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1470635

Change-Id: Ie7ff88b8cbb23b3ca149cb6e8d5a18a427d22038
Partially-Implements: blueprint ansible-service
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/33/198533/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Start the api to set initial endpoint and users with the admin_token $CMD sleep 5 openstack service create --name keystone \ --description "OpenStack Identity" identity openstack endpoint create --region "${REGION_NAME}" \ --publicurl "${PUBLIC_URL}" \ --internalurl "${INTERNAL_URL}" \ --adminurl "${ADMIN_URL}" identity openstack project create --description "Admin Project" admin openstack user create --password "${KEYSTONE_ADMIN_PASSWORD}" admin openstack role create admin openstack role add --project admin --user admin admin

commit_message:
Add v1 API deprecation warnings

Also add warnings on the different use of "description" fields in API V1 VS V2

Change-Id: Ie02fe85133d083570d7b6633fdaa84614c77f78a
Closes-Bug: 1466568
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/66/198066/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: V1 API has been deprecated since the Kilo release. .. note:: The "description" field on Records cannot be accessed from the V2 API. Likewise, the "description" field on Record Sets cannot be accessed from the V1 API.

subject: [EDP] Unified Map to Define Job Interface
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-02 23:16:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara/commit/f455ebf79997bb6da17aab218dc5ccbe29395977', 'message': '[WIP][EDP] Unified Map to Define Job Interface

This change adds an "interface" map to the API for job creation, such that
the operator registering a job can define a unified, human-readable way to
pass in all arguments, parameters, and configurations that the execution
of that job may require or accept. This will allow platform-agnostic
wizarding at the job execution phase and allows users to document use of
their own jobs once in a persistent, standardized format.

WIP-related text follows:

Known issues with current patch include:
1) Lack of unit or integration testing (posting to allow early review of
structural concerns; please don't feel obligated to comb too closely for
nits yet: I expect to find many over the course of testing.)
2) Security around secret defaults/execution args.
3) Validation of the existence and nonexistence of input and output data
types.
4) Lack of API documentation or feature documentation.
5) On implementation, I am wholly uncertain that the execution arguments
table needs to exist. To be discussed.

Putting this up as a WIP now that development testing of the happy path is
successful, as given the scope of the change, positive feedback which will
alter in-progress tests is almost inevitable.

Change-Id: I59b9b679a650361ddcd30975891496fdfbabb93c
Implements: blueprint unified-job-interface-map
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-06-03 17:13:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara/commit/1da49ba0a27164989880c352de18dd05d201eb65', 'message': '[WIP][EDP] Unified Map to Define Job Interface

commit_message:
[EDP] Unified Map to Define Job Interface

This change adds an "interface" map to the API for job creation, such that
the operator registering a job can define a unified, human-readable way to
pass in all arguments, parameters, and configurations that the execution
of that job may require or accept. This will allow platform-agnostic
wizarding at the job execution phase and allows users to document use of
their own jobs once in a persistent, standardized format.

Change-Id: I59b9b679a650361ddcd30975891496fdfbabb93c
Partially Implements: blueprint unified-job-interface-map

commit_message:
Modify run_tests.sh to support PostgreSQL

Modify run_tests.sh to run unit tests with PostgreSQL. Fix a number of
connection pool and deadlock related issues in the unit tests. Fix DB
clean up routine to remove records in the correct context and order.

Change-Id: If88c00a326c025af885d061ca95588939195b7c5
Implements: blueprint run-unit-tests-on-postgresql

commit_message:
Bump check-ironic-inspector-dsvm-nv timeout to usual 2 hours

It's an insane amount of time for such a simple job, and under normal
conditions it does not take more than 30 minutes. However, we are
suffering from https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2000310
and this change may reduce failure rate.

Change-Id: Ia0e1de69d99bf9321c942ee5af08a930da63538c

commit_message:
Ensure test_find_zone_imports waits for all imports

test_find_zone_imports was only waiting for a single zone
import to complete, rather than both of the imports created
during the tests to complete. This resulted in occasional
failures in the gate if the second import finished before
the first.

Change-Id: Iad2b518b3e4bccded305de2ee3e7fdbbf82095f8
Closes-Bug: 1470854

commit_message:
Minor readability changes to the preface

A couple of the phrases were a bit awkward (e.g., "conducting" a
solution).  Other changes are more straight-forward but all are
subjective, so discussion is quite welcome.

subject: Move volumes data from the core into volume manager extension
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-30 17:32:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/c96daca1c448f2f38e55c8ebb95bd5ceb6314b47', 'message': "Move volumes data from the core into volume manager extension

Migration the data from core into an extension is not
a trivial problem, ideally extension should know nothing
about core's fields in the database and vice versa.

We had several options:
1. move data migration into an extension, it's a bad
   option, because in migration we should drop
   node.attributes.volumes column, it's a very bad
   thing to do, because only core's migrations should
   be responsible for managing of core's db schema
2. implement everethyng in the core, cannot be implemented
   for the same reasons as for 1st option, in this
   case we should run extension's db migration in
   order to create required fields and then
   in core migration hardcode table's name to migrate
   the data
3. use shared table, in this case core's responsibility
   is to just put all of the data from core's models
   into predefined table and drop node.attributes.volumes column,
   extension migration script's responsibility is to check
   if in predefined table there are data for this specific
   extension, and retrieve these data if there are any

We've decided to use shared table (3rd option) because it's
better option then two others.

Implements blueprint: volume-manager-refactoring
Change-Id: I6f03a535edab18e6d9e53a47fc4abdd381a3495f

commit_message:
Move volumes data from the core into volume manager extension

Migration the data from core into an extension is not
a trivial problem, ideally extension should know nothing
about core's fields in the database and vice versa.

We had several options:
1. move data migration into an extension, it's a bad
   option, because in migration we should drop
   node.attributes.volumes column, it's a very bad
   thing to do, because only core's migrations should
   be responsible for managing of core's db schema
2. implement everything in the core, cannot be implemented
   for the same reasons as for 1st option, in this
   case we should run extension's db migration in
   order to create required fields and then
   in core migration hardcode table's name to migrate
   the data
3. use shared table, in this case core's responsibility
   is to just put all of the data from core's models
   into predefined table and drop node.attributes.volumes column,
   extension migration script's responsibility is to check
   if in predefined table there are data for this specific
   extension, and retrieve these data if there are any

We've decided to use shared table (3rd option) because it's
better option then two others.

Another change is we are not going to use extension version
as a prefix for extension tables. As result we will
not have two extension with the same name, but different
version installed at the same time. Using version in
table names dramatically increase complexity of extension
update.

Implements blueprint: volume-manager-refactoring
Change-Id: I6f03a535edab18e6d9e53a47fc4abdd381a3495f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/90/197190/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
FA: oslo.serialization -> oslo_serialization

The issue is that oslo log module tries to
import oslo.serialization which is depricated.
Correct way to import this is to use
oslo_serialization module name.

The correct way how to fix this would be
installing oslo_log module instead of using
log module from oslo-incubator. But this way
is going to take long time because there are
no corresponding rpm and deb packages available.

TODO: use oslo_log instead of log module from oslo-incubator
when rpm and deb packages are available

Change-Id: I866fa0e19c5b872a82af6739d3537c24916bccc1
Closes-Bug: #1472018

commit_message:
Remove hotref links in the documentation

Now that we moved the template_guide in-tree, the hotref sphinx
directive doesn't work anymore and isn't needed. This replaces it with
ref directives and a missing-reference handler managing resources.

Change-Id: I5cba4b96894878a57d577c74dd6ade7fd252b164

commit_message:
Filter - aggregate flavour extra spec affinity filter

This spec introduces a new filter to allow an operator
to define required instance extra specifications for a
host aggregate.

Change-Id: I1a0bc7f9137e6698b893799e6e057995d238d7d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/76/183876/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================================== Filter - aggregate flavour extra spec affinity filter ===================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/aggregate-type-extra-specs-affinity-filter This blueprint introduces a new filter to the nova filter scheduler. This blueprint does not modify or define any new flavour extra spec key/value pairs. This blueprint will introduce a new flavor_extra_spec host aggregates metadata key/value pair. The flavor_extra_spec metadata pair will be consumed by the AggregateTypeExtraSpecsAffinityFilter to allow operators to define a set of extra specs key value pairs that are required to schedule to the aggregate. Problem description =================== At present the filter_scheduler allows operators to associate a single instance type with a host aggregate via the AggregateTypeAffinityFilter [1][2] or to enforce that an aggregate satisfies any extra specifications associated with the instance type via the AggregateInstanceExtraSpecsFilter[3], but does not allow an operator to enforce that any extra specifications associated with an aggregate are requested by an instance. This blueprint introduces a new filter to address this gap. Use Cases ---------- hw:mem_page_size is used in the use case below but this is equally applicable to any extra spec keypair. 1) An operator has many flavours which define multiple tiers of memory backings as well as other extra specs. The operator wants to optimise the scheduler by first filtering on host aggregate flavor_extra_spec and then filtering the remaining host with the NUMATopologyFilter. this use case can be supported by placing the AggregateTypeExtraSpecsAffinityFilter before the NUMATopologyFilter in the scheduler_default_filters and defining appropriate host aggregates e.g. standard memory backing aggregate: flavor_extra_spec: "hw:mem_page_size=small,hw:mem_page_size=any" high bandwidth memory backing aggregate: flavor_extra_spec: "hw:mem_page_size=2M,hw:mem_page_size=1G,hw:mem_page_size=large" 2) An operator has multiple page sizes allocated on each node. They have deployed open stack in a ha environment and co located some OpenStack services with nova compute to evenly distribute network storage and CPU load across there could infrastructure. To optimise this deployment the operator wants to define host aggregate reflect how the reflect how services are co-located and to limit what resources can be requested when scheduling. NFV aggregate: flavor_extra_spec: "hw:mem_page_size=2M" hosts in this aggregate are configured with 4k,2M and 1G hugepages. each node is deployed with an nfv optimised vswitch that utilises 1G hugepages for maximum throughput. The nova vcpu_pin_set and kernel isolcpus parameters are used to isolate instances to cores not used by co-located services. The nova-compute service is co-located with the neutron l3 agent with dvr enabled to further optimise tenant networking in this aggregate. With the flavor_extra_spec definition above only vm that request 2M hugepages will be scheduled to this node. The 1G hugepages will be reserved for vswitch and the standard 4k pages will be reserved for openstack and host os services. API aggregate: flavor_extra_spec: "hw:mem_page_size=small,hw:mem_page_size=any" hosts in this aggregate are configured with standard 4k pages and 1G hugepages. the nova-compute service is co-located with RabbitMQ, MySQL and OpenStack api endpoints. API endpoints, RabbitMQ and MySQL are co-located to reduce api latency. To optimise database performance MySQL is configured to use hugepages[4]. The nova vcpu_pin_set and kernel isolcpus parameters are used to isolate instances to cores not used by co-located services. With the flavor_extra_spec definition above only vms which request small or any memory backing are scheduled to this aggregate. Project Priority ----------------- TBD/None Proposed change =============== A new host aggregates metadata entry flavor_extra_spec will be added. The value of flavor_extra_spec is a string containing a list of required instance type extra spec keys and values. The content of the list will be formatted as follows. The entries in the list will be separated by commas without white space. Each entry will comprise of a instance type extra spec key followed by and equals "=" followed by a value. Entry format <key>=<value> e.g. "hw:mem_page_size=small" The sentinel value asterisk "*" may be used to specify that any value is valid if the key is present. e.g. "hw:mem_page_size=*" The sentinel value tilde "~" may be used to specify that a key may optionally be omitted. e.g. "hw:mem_page_size=any,hw:mem_page_size=~" The sentinel value exclamation mark "!" may be used to specify that the key must not be present. e.g. "hw:mem_page_size=!" The asterisk,tilde and exclamation mark sentinels are mutually exclusive and may only appear once per key. A new filter class AggregateTypeExtraSpecsAffinityFilter will be implement and added to nova/scheduler/filters/type_filter.py. The rules governing when as host is passed are detailed below. For brevity only the rules for entries with explicit non sentinel values are given. if a host belongs to no host aggregates or the host aggregate does not have flavor_extra_spec metadata defined the filter will pass this host. if a host belongs to a host aggregate containing a flavor_extra_spec key that is not requested by the instance extra specs or if that value requested does not match the value specified in the flavor_extra_spec the host will not be passed by this filter. if a host belongs to a host aggregates whose flavor_extra_spec metadata is a subset or identity of the instance type extra specs the host will be passed by this filter. Alternatives ------------ A combination of the AggregateTypeAffinityFilter the AggregateInstanceExtraSpecsFilter and carefully designed flavours could be configured to achieve the same granularity of control. This would require considerably more effort to design and configure then the filter described in this proposal. Data model impact ----------------- None The flavor_extra_spec keypair will reuse the existing host aggregate metadata data model and will not require any modifications. REST API impact --------------- None the flavor_extra_spec keypair will reuse the existing api for setting host aggregate metadata. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ This filter will be optionally and will only take effect when configured by the deployer. This filter provides a potential optimisation point for an operator to tune the performance of the nova filter scheduler by creating host aggregate and defining flavor_extra_spec metadata values for common extra spec values based on there knowledge of there deployment. Other deployer impact --------------------- To enable this feature the AggregateTypeExtraSpecsAffinityFilter will have to be added to the scheduler_default_filters in the nova.conf When enabling this filter the ordering of this filter and other should be considered and adjusted to optimise the filtering process. In general filters that remove large amounts of host and are computationally cheap should be first. filters that remove few hosts and are computationally intensive should be last. The optimum ordering of this filter will depend on the deployment could configuration, its workload and the host aggregate flavor_extra_spec defined. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Rodolfo (will need to add launchpad-id) Other contributors: sean-k-mooney Work Items ---------- * implement filter class in nova/scheduler/filters/type_filter.py * add developer documentation to doc/source/devref/filter_scheduler.rst * implement unit tests Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit test will be provided but no other testing should be required. Documentation Impact ==================== developer documentation will be updated as noted above. References ========== [1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/scheduler/filters/type_filter.py [2] Allow multiple instance types https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1399204 [3] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/scheduler/filters/aggregate_instance_extra_specs.py [4] https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/large-page-support.html

commit_message:
Remove name field from fields in dynamic UI

This spec is intent to make from definitions less demanding

Change-Id: I97f4371e588b8c73d2e7ef55eb1f4f3c686d5356
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-specs refs/changes/40/137340/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================ Remove name field from fields and object model in dynamic UI ============================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/murano/+spec/dynamic-ui-specify-no-explicit-name-field Now name is a required parameter in every singe form definition. But Murano engine doesn't know anything about this parameter. It mostly uses for dymanic UI purposes. So we can insert this field automatically in every form. Problem description =================== *'name'* parameter is acceptable parameter by Murano engine. Now all unknown parameters are ignores, but lately the error will be spawn and all applications will be invalid. To prevent global fail this change is suggested. Proposed change =============== Add automatic field inserting into the first form and store 'name' field value in attribute storage. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Versioning impact ------------------------- Backward compatibility will be supported by checking existence of 'name' field in UI definition Other end user impact --------------------- None Deployer impact --------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Murano-dashboard / Horizon impact --------------------------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <efedorova> Work Items ---------- * Check for name field in form definition and add to the first Application's form if doesn't exist * Extract 'name' field value into designer attributes storage * Use 'name' from designer attributes storage in environments table * Remove 'name' references from existing Applications markup Dependencies ============ This change is a dependency for a future changes in engine Testing ======= CI tests should be updated and catch all errors. Documentation Impact ==================== Dynamic UI form definition examples should be updated References ========== None

Unit-tests for fuel-migrate script

Change-Id: I62ad5a85ccd93a81cdd647b72261973a9523755b
Related-Blueprint: reduced-footprint

added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env bats # For testing is bats framework https://github.com/sstephenson/bats fms="$BATS_TEST_DIRNAME/../../files/fuel-migrate/fuel-migrate" load "$fms" fuel_astute="$BATS_TMPDIR/test.yaml" fuel_migrate_vars="$BATS_TMPDIR/.var" echo "--- ADMIN_NETWORK: cidr: 10.20.0.0/24 dhcp_gateway: "172.16.58.68" dhcp_pool_start: "172.16.58.70" dhcp_pool_end: "172.16.58.92" interface: eth9 ipaddress: "1.22.222.1" mac: "52:54:00:d6:6f:9e" netmask: "255.0.255.0" size: "256" HOSTNAME: fuel-slab2 NTP1: 0.pool.ntp.org ">${fuel_astute} @test "Check help message" { run usage [ $status -eq 1 ] [ "${lines[0]}" = "Usage:" ] } @test "Check usage with error notification" { run usage "custom message" [ $status -eq 1 ] [ "${lines[0]}" = "custom message" ] } @test "Check yaml parser" { run yaml_var $fuel_astute ADMIN_NETWORK ipaddress [ "${lines[0]}" = "1.22.222.1" ] run yaml_var $fuel_astute ADMIN_NETWORK interface [ "${lines[0]}" = "eth9" ] run yaml_var $fuel_astute ADMIN_NETWORK netmask [ "${lines[0]}" = "255.0.255.0" ] } @test "Check mytrim" { run mytrim two one [ "${lines[0]}" = "two" ] } @test "Check save_vars" { varone=one run save_vars varone run cat ${fuel_migrate_vars} [ "${lines[1]}" = 'varone="one"' ] } @test "Check ifaces transformer" { other_net_bridges="eth1,br10,,ems1,virbr1,<xml test >," IFS="," run ifaces $other_net_bridges IFS=" " [ "${lines[0]}" = " <interface type='bridge'>" ] [ "${lines[1]}" = " <source bridge='br10'/>" ] [ "${lines[2]}" = " <target dev='vfm_eth1'/>" ] [ "${lines[3]}" = " <model type='virtio'/>" ] [ "${lines[4]}" = " </interface>" ] [ "${lines[5]}" = " <interface type='bridge'>" ] [ "${lines[6]}" = " <source bridge='virbr1'/>" ] [ "${lines[7]}" = " <target dev='vfm_ems1'/>" ] [ "${lines[8]}" = "<xml test >" ] [ "${lines[9]}" = " <model type='virtio'/>" ] [ "${lines[10]}" = " </interface>" ] } @test "Check echo with indent" { indent="----------" wtw="20" long_long_var=" word1 word11 01234567890123456789012345 word111\ word1111 word11111" run echo_indent $long_long_var [ "${lines[0]}" = "---------- word1 word11" ] [ "${lines[1]}" = "---------- 01234567890123456789012345" ] [ "${lines[2]}" = "---------- word111 word1111" ] [ "${lines[3]}" = "---------- word11111" ] } @test "Check clone_part_str" { src_bs="512" dst_bs="1024" pcount="1" param=" 1 34 49152 24.0 MiB EF02 primary" run clone_part_str $param [ "${lines[0]}" = " -n1:17: -t 1:EF02 -c 1:primary" ] pcount="2" run clone_part_str $param [ "${lines[0]}" = " -n1:17:24576 -t 1:EF02 -c 1:primary" ] }

commit_message:
Optimize Rally imports to reduce start time

* Load plugins only if they are required
  This reduce a lot starting time of Rally and will
  allows us to do online bash completition

  As well it cleans up project structure a lot, e.g.
  all plugins are loaded in single place +
  we don't have strange code in cliutils

* Replace rally.ui.utils to not import mako
  and remove all code on module level

* Make Rally DB lazy inited

* Import plugins during test run

----

The best way to test changes in start up time is to
compare "time rally version" e.g.:

before this patch:
$ time rally version
0.0.5
real	0m0.397s
user	0m0.299s
sys	0m0.089s

after this patch:
0.0.5

real	0m0.281s
user	0m0.200s
sys	0m0.077s

Change-Id: Ibec2e6da66a1304730e801de307df7a1da68d51f

commit_message:
Run neutron multinode without dvr

We had been running tempest full only against neutron + DVR in a
multinode env. Add a second job to run without DVR as we don't want DVR
blocking other multinode work and we may be adding additional non DVR
test setups.

Change-Id: Icb52a0389689fcebb61b3cef5e2881a56723cd30

commit_message:
Fuel Agent: oslo_log instead of oslo.log

Added oslo_log package into requirements.txt
because it is now available as a separate package.
Besides it has been removed from oslo-incubator.

Change-Id: I5c858b178caf481d76cf9a6e352ecb64eb438c79
Closes-Bug: #1472018

extension which will be used inband raid configuration
in Ironic

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/60/196960/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @base.async_command('create_raid_configuration') def create_raid_configuration(self, raid_config): """Create raid configuration on the bare metal server. This method routes the call to the appropriate hardware manager. :param raid_config: The RAID config JSON dictionary as provided by the user in Ironic :returns: the value returned by the hardware manager which is expected to be the current raid configuration after applying it. """ return hardware.dispatch_to_managers('create_raid_configuration', raid_config=raid_config) @base.async_command('delete_raid_configuration') def delete_raid_configuration(self): """Delete raid configuration on the bare metal server. This method routes the call to the appropriate hardware manager. :returns: the value returned by the hardware manager which is expected to be the current raid configuration after deleting it. """ return hardware.dispatch_to_managers('delete_raid_configuration')

commit_message:
Remove unused fields "from_*" from API controller

Remove the fields below:
* magnum.api.controllers.v1.bay.BaysController.from_bays
* magnum.api.controllers.v1.baymodel.BayModelController.from_baymodels
* magnum.api.controllers.v1.container.ContainersController.from_containers
* magnum.api.controllers.v1.node.NodesController.from_nodes
* magnum.api.controllers.v1.pod.PodsController.from_pods
* magnum.api.controllers.v1.service.ServicesController.from_services
* magnum.api.controllers.v1.replicationcontroller.
      ReplicationControllersController.from_rcs

These fields were ported from Ironic at the very beginning of the
project, and they are unused so far. Also remove OperationNotPermitted
exception since it is not used anymore.

Change-Id: Ie655b95dd4325641278fc195fa2032f60087b3fa
Closes-Bug: 1471431

subject: Replace is_hostname_safe with a better check
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-19 14:58:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/ff2bb7f7caa528008c626adc2876a2efd817ace1', 'message': 'Improve is_hostname_safe check

Performance:

* Use a single precompiled regex to do the check instead of building a
  new regex on the fly each time, and separate endswith() and regex
  checks.
* Do not keep matching groups, since they are not used.

Correctness:

* Hostnames are case insensitive (RFC 952: "No distinction is made
  between upper and lower case"), so make the regex case insensitive
  too.
* Underscores are valid in DNS names, but *not* in hostnames; do not
  allow them in _is_hostname_safe.
* Every label in a hostname has the same format, and they all must
  start with a letter or number, not a dash.

Other:

* Build the regex in one step using re.X for improved readability,
  instead of bodging it together over several steps.
* Minor unit test improvements.

Change-Id: I77441ae5a00e52b84051672ecab5785dd0b033a5
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-06-19 16:45:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/5d989b9ed4c30ba9cbb81d3e679d1c7f29430401', 'message': 'Improve is_hostname_safe check

Performance:

* Use a single precompiled regex to do the check instead of building a
  new regex on the fly each time, and separate endswith() and regex
  checks.
* Do not keep matching groups, since they are not used.

Correctness:

* Hostnames are case insensitive (RFC 952: "No distinction is made
  between upper and lower case"), so make the regex case insensitive
  too.
* Underscores are valid in DNS names, but *not* in hostnames; do not
  allow them in _is_hostname_safe.
* Every label in a hostname has the same format, and they all must
  start with a letter or number, not a dash.
* 'hostname' is shorthand for 'hostname.', so the true maximum length
  of a hostname is 253 characters (254 octets).

Other:

* Build the regex in one step using re.X for improved readability,
  instead of bodging it together over several steps.
* Minor unit test improvements.

Change-Id: I77441ae5a00e52b84051672ecab5785dd0b033a5

is_hostname_safe was broken in several ways, which are documented in
bug #1468508. This replaces is_hostname_safe with a
is_valid_logical_name, which checks that logical names contain only
RFC 3986 unreserved characters, which is what was decided upon in the
Ironic meeting on 29 June 2015.

A new API microversion, 1.9, is introduced to handle this change.

Additionally, the performance of the old is_hostname_safe() is
improved in several ways.

Fixes-Bug: 1468508 1434376
Change-Id: I77441ae5a00e52b84051672ecab5785dd0b033a5
'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2015-06-30 18:46:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/9b6851fa1db22be8ff75c32100b15e534fa8e2f9', 'message': 'Replace is_hostname_safe with a better check

commit_message:
Replace is_hostname_safe with a better check

is_hostname_safe was broken in several ways, which are documented in
bug #1468508. This replaces is_hostname_safe with a
is_valid_logical_name, which checks that logical names contain only
RFC 3986 unreserved characters, which is what was decided upon in the
Ironic meeting on 29 June 2015.

A new API microversion, 1.10, is introduced to handle this change.

Additionally, the performance of the old is_hostname_safe() is
improved in several ways.

Closes-Bug: #1468508
Closes-Bug: #1434376
Change-Id: I77441ae5a00e52b84051672ecab5785dd0b033a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/87/193587/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: _is_hostname_safe_re = re.compile(r"""^ [a-z0-9] # start with a number or letter (?:[a-z0-9\-]{0,61} # followed by up to 61 letters/numbers/dashes [a-z0-9])? # and end with a letter or number (?:\. # subsequent labels are separated by dots [a-z0-9] # start with a number or letter (?:[a-z0-9\-]{0,61} # followed by up to 61 letters/numbers/dashes [a-z0-9])? # and end with a letter or number )* # any number of labels \.? # optionally end with a dot $""", re.I | re.X) if not isinstance(hostname, six.string_types) or len(hostname) > 253: return _is_hostname_safe_re.match(hostname) is not None
deleted_lines: if not isinstance(hostname, six.string_types) or len(hostname) > 255: # Periods on the end of a hostname are ok, but complicates the # regex so we'll do this manually if hostname.endswith('.'): hostname = hostname[:-1] host = '[a-z0-9]([a-z0-9\-]{0,61}[a-z0-9])?' domain = '[a-z0-9\-_]{0,62}[a-z0-9]' m = '^' + host + '(\.' + domain + ')*$' return re.match(m, hostname) is not None

commit_message:
Adjust yaql version in upper-constraints

Pin yaql to 0.2.6. 0.3.0 should be excluded and is already excluded
in global-requirements.txt, but commit b0eddd76 landed after
upper-constraints.txt was introduced.

Current version of yaql (0.3.0) blocks Murano dsvm jobs.

Change-Id: Icc0d2c2c796d21cd93b2211f23dbb75c68e307a6

commit_message:
Generic rpc callback mechanism which could be reused

This is a publisher/subscriber messaging mechanism optimized
for agent consumption and server production without the need
of creating new rpc messages when new resources are introduced.

Oslo versionedobjects are the perfect match to ensure
cross version compatibility even if the published/subscribed
resources format change over time.

This is still a basic stub allowing get_info of the resources,
and the next change will introduce the RPC methods to call
get_info: I0ac8a009e781b6edb283d8634b1a2f047db092dc

The plugin is returning stub objects to be consumed from the
agent to test the basic behaviour until we have DB.

TODO: Update documentation, according to code changes,
      enforce versioned objects only doing deserial/serialization.

Co-Authored-By: Miguel Angel Ajo <mangelajo@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Eran Gampel <eran@gampel.net>

Change-Id: I524cf5a14e99dc6bee4d4261557d98c75efa0809
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/35/190635/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================= Neutron Messaging Callback System ================================= In Neutron, agents may need to subscribe to specific resource details which may change over time. Such updates need to be done in a very modular way without creating new messages, or changing core implementation for every new detail. One example of those could be security groups members and rules or QoS profiles over ports or network resources. Using a remote publisher/subscriber pattern, the information about such resources could be published using fanout queues to all interested nodes, minimizing messaging requests from agents to server. Additionally, if we leveraged oslo.versionedobjects capabilities to serialize and deserialize objects we could easily make them version independent across model updates and agent versions. Subscribing to resources ======================== Imagine that you have agent A, which just got to handle a new port, which has associated SG-A, and QoS-profile-A uuids both. At that moment, the agent may subscribe: :: from neutron.rpc_resources import resources from neutron.rpc_resources import registry def process_resource_updates(resource_type, resource_id, resource_lis): ... send to the right handler which will update any control plane details related to the updated resource... def port_update(...): ... sg_rules = registry.get_info(resources.SG_RULES, sg_id, callback=process_resource_updates) sg_members = registry.get_info(resources.SG_MEMBERS, sg_id, callback=process_resource_updates) qos_rules = registry.get_info(resources.QOS_RULES, qos_profile_id) cleanup_subscriptions() def cleaup_subscriptions() sg_ids = determine_unreferenced_sg_ids() qos_profile_ids = determine_unreferenced_sg_ids() registry.unsubscribe_info(resource.SG_RULES, sg_ids) registry.unsubscribe_info(resource.SG_MEMBERS, sg_ids) registry.unsubscribe_info(resource.QOS_RULES, qos_profile_ids) Unsubscribing to resources ========================== There are a few options to unsubscribe registered callbacks: * unsubscribe_info(): it selectively unsubscribes an specific resource + id. * unsubscribe_resource(): it unsubscribes from an specific resource, any ID. * unsubscribe_all(): it unsubscribes all subscribed resources and ids. registry.subscribe(callback2, resources.ROUTER_GATEWAY, events.BEFORE_UPDATE) print 'Subscribed' Sending resource updates ======================== On the server side, resource updates could come from anywhere, a service plugin, an extension, anything that updates the resource and that it's of any interest to the agents. :: from neutron.rpc_resources import resource from neutron.rpc_resources import registry as rpc_registry def add_qos_x_rule(...): update_the_db(...) send_rpc_updates_on_qos_profile(qos_profile_id) def send_rpc_updates_on_qos_profile(qos_profile_id): rules = get_qos_profile_rules(qos_profile_id) rpc_registry.notify(resource.QOS_RULES, qos_profile_id, rules)

Components that mean special things to the local file system (e.g. drive or directory names) are ignored. (XXX They should probably be diagnosed.) """ # abandon query parameters path = path.split('?', 1)[0] path = path.split('#', 1)[0] path = posixpath.normpath(urllib.unquote(path)) words = path.split('/') words = filter(None, words) path = self.docroot for word in words: drive, word = os.path.splitdrive(word) head, word = os.path.split(word) path = os.path.join(path, word) return path def log_message(self, format, *args): self.logger.info(format % args) def __init__(self, document_root): self.port = get_free_port() self.document_root = document_root def handler_factory(*args, **kwargs): return HttpServer.Handler(document_root, *args, **kwargs) self._server = BaseHTTPServer.HTTPServer( ('', self.port), handler_factory) self._thread = Thread(target=self._server.serve_forever) self._thread.daemon = True def start(self): self._thread.start() def run(self): self._thread.join() def stop(self): self._server.shutdown() self._thread.join() def http_server(document_root): server = HttpServer(document_root) server.start() return server with open(path) as file: current = file.tell() try: file.seek(0, 2) size = file.tell() finally: file.seek(current) return size

commit_message:
Refactoring of environment.py

- Removed unnecessary iterations with all(map(...))
- Better use of Django QuerySets
- Promote function reuse
- Get rid of some nested if's
- Remove unnecessary dict.get's

Change-Id: I74725d5ea4afd0f0f86dbb93f8846dbe0edc8f86

commit_message:
Fix wrong check when create image without data.

The default value of 'locations' is [].So there is a wrong check in
db/sqlalchemy/api.py.
When create an image without data, The function '_image_locations_set'
should not be executed.

Change-Id: Ie4cb29ab0d714d3ce67f717d5eaf641424efa5b7
Closes-bug:#1471080

commit_message:
Allow setting virtual-size during image create

Change Ie4f58ee2e4da3a6c1229840295c7f62023a95b70 added support for a new image
attribute, virtual_size, for API v2. However, there isn't a way for the user
to set this value, as it is read-only. In the future, glance should set this
virtual_size via introspection. Since that is not possible at the moment,
let the user set it when they create the instance.

Change-Id: Ifb550ba250feddd77555d500bdceb4dd8b8db43e

commit_message:
Revert "Enable version discovery"

This reverts commit ae03d2a721bd9acb61805ce792a27fb7cf88e5cd.

Cases where a deployment is using a proxy, Cinder servers won't return
the expected publicURL, and instead gives an internal URL that the
client can't use.

Commit 2eb25ab8803214cb3beb5d8fe3efbf70a462c414 in Cinder introduces the
public_endpoint config option, but not everyone is expected to be
running that later of a version to take advantage of this.

Closes-Bug: #1464160
Change-Id: I61228c1e8630b958c792be077674b48fbdb83135

commit_message:
Add heat template-function-list command

Implements bp: template-function-list
APIImpact

Change-Id: I1edc90dc27272e4ab9392562f07ae0686ba8fc71
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/64/188364/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================ Heat template functions list ============================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/template-function-list Add an ability to get the list of available functions for given template by cmd Problem description =================== There is no such possibility in heat now. It is useful for helping template writers Proposed change =============== Add following command to heat CLI: ``heat template-function-list <template>`` Where `template` is the one template name from `heat template-version-list` command output. Description of this one may be found in [1] Corresponding REST API would be the following: ``GET on /template_versions/<template>`` Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- skraynev ochuprykov Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: liberty-1 Work Items ---------- * Update Resource REST API controller with additional capabilities * Update the heat CLI * Add required RPC * Add required additional test cases. * Add documentation for CLI (python-heatclient), REST API (api-sites) Dependencies ============ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/188351/ References ========== [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/template-function-list

commit_message:
Add 55572 to the reserved ports list for murano

This change adds 55572 to the reserved ports list for murano. Without
this change, some deployments fail occastionally when port 55572 is in
use.

Change-Id: If62504a5b3b7110d35278fe3654cdbb35dbbe194
Closes-Bug: 1467024
(cherry picked from commit 65f42673adb4c32e6021db975a2212b569eeccd8)

commit_message:
Move devstack-external-plugins spec into implemented

This commit moves the devstack-external-plugins spec into the
implemented dir. This bp was closed some time ago but the spec
approval fell through the cracks and was only merged recently.
Additionally the recent patch to do a mass cleanup of all the
specs missed this move to implemented. So let's take care of
it now.

As part of this the devstack specs line in the index is commented
out because this was the last open devstack spec. Without any open
specs in the devstack dir sphinx will warn on there being no files,
which we treat as a fatal error in ci.

Change-Id: Icf4d96ac46c5abdec5f7036d10d5e249d8471a73
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/qa-specs refs/changes/79/198179/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Stop checking the status of node if nova boot fails
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-07 03:11:55.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/exercise.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector/commit/d3f1909b1d3535319ab1e4b8f9fc5d441af563c4', 'message': 'Stop checking the status of node if nova boot fails

devstack/exercise.sh tries to check the status of node at the most 30 times
otherwise "nova boot" fails.
If the status of node is ERROR, trying to check the status makes no sence
anymore.

This patch set fix this. If "nova boot" fails, devstack/exercise.sh doesn't
try to check the status of node anymore.

Change-Id: Ia4d279acad977833c16c57d7bc9677275de38504
'}]
commit_message:
Stop checking the status of node if nova boot fails

devstack/exercise.sh tries to check the status of node at the most 30 times
otherwise "nova boot" fails.
If the status of node is ERROR, trying to check the status makes no sence
anymore.

This patch set fix this. If "nova boot" fails, devstack/exercise.sh doesn't
try to check the status of node anymore.

Change-Id: Ia4d279acad977833c16c57d7bc9677275de38504

Improve asserting XML in tests

Comparing XML as strings is not a good idea. Let's use a
dedicated assertions that will help with checking XML.

commit_message:
Allow to do not use CPU 'host-model'

In some cases 'host-model' mode for CPU settings may cause kernel panics.
To fix this issue new setting DRIVER_USE_HOST_CPU was added.
If enabled (by default) 'host-model' is used, if disabled default mode
(which is "custom") is used.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1464551

Change-Id: Id275d1b0371981c02d9727539caa46e531e73557
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-devops refs/changes/89/190989/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add new build script

This new build script is written entirely in python and supports
multithreading to speed up the builds.

Partially-Implements: blueprint build-script
Change-Id: Ia630e5a83951ec37706a9596427024f3b7c10ba7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/17/196617/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python import sys import os from threading import Thread import Queue import time import tempfile import shutil import datetime import argparse import subprocess class Object(object): pass class WorkerThread(Thread): def __init__(self, queue): self.queue = queue Thread.__init__(self) def run(self): """ Executes tasks until the queue is empty """ while True: try: data = self.queue.get(block=False) builder(data) self.queue.task_done() except Queue.Empty: break except: traceback.print_exc() self.queue.task_done() def builder(image): #path to Dockerfile #subprocess.call(['docker', 'build', '--rm', '-t', image['fullname'], image['path']], stdout=subprocess.PIPE) subprocess.call(['docker', 'build', '--rm', '-t', image['fullname'], image['path']]) def argParser(): parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description='Kolla build script') parser.add_argument('-n','--namespace', help='Set the Docker namespace name', type=str, default='kollaglue' ) parser.add_argument('--tag', help='Set the Docker tag', type=str, default='latest' ) parser.add_argument('-b','--base', help='The base distro to use when building', type=str, default='centos' ) parser.add_argument('-t','--type', help='The method of the Openstack install', type=str, default='binary' ) parser.add_argument('-T','--threads', help='The number of threads to use while building', type=int, default=8 ) return vars(parser.parse_args()) class KollaWorker(): def __init__(self, base, type_): self.kolla_dir = sys.path[0] + '/..' self.images_dir = self.kolla_dir + '/docker' self.base = base self.type_ = type_ def setupWorkingDir(self): """ Creates a working directory for use while building """ ts = time.time() ts = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(ts).strftime('%Y-%m-%d_%H-%M-%S_') self.temp_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp(prefix='kolla-' + ts) self.working_dir = self.temp_dir + '/docker' shutil.copytree(self.images_dir, self.working_dir) def findDockerfiles(self): """ Recursive search for Dockerfiles in the working directory """ self.docker_build_paths = list() path = self.working_dir + '/' + self.base + '/' + self.type_ for root, dirs, names in os.walk(path): if 'Dockerfile' in names: self.docker_build_paths.append(root) def cleanup(self): """ Remove temp files """ shutil.rmtree(self.temp_dir) def sortImages(self): """ Build images dependacy tiers """ images_to_process = self.images self.tiers = list() while images_to_process: self.tiers.append(list()) processed_images = list() for image in images_to_process: if image['parent'] == None: self.tiers[-1].append(image) processed_images.append(image) try: for parent in self.tiers[-2]: if image['parent'] == parent['fullname']: self.tiers[-1].append(image) processed_images.append(image) except IndexError: pass if not processed_images: print('Could not find parent image from some images. Aborting') for image in images_to_process: print(image['name'], image['parent']) sys.exit() for image in processed_images: images_to_process.remove(image) def buildQueues(self, namespace, prefix, tag): """ Return a list of Queues that have been organized into a hierarchy based on dependencies """ self.images = list() # Walk all of the Dockerfiles and replace the %%KOLLA%% variables for path in self.docker_build_paths: with open(path + '/Dockerfile') as f: content = f.read().replace('%%KOLLA_NAMESPACE%%', namespace) content = content.replace('%%KOLLA_PREFIX%%', prefix) content = content.replace('%%KOLLA_TAG%%', tag) with open(path + '/Dockerfile', 'w') as f: f.write(content) image = dict() image['name'] = os.path.basename(path) image['fullname'] = namespace + '/' + prefix + image['name'] \ + ':' + tag image['path'] = path image['parent'] = content.split(' ')[1].split('\n')[0] if not namespace in image['parent']: image['parent'] = None self.images.append(image) self.sortImages() pools = list() for tier in self.tiers: pool = Queue.Queue() for image in tier: pool.put(image) pools.append(pool) return pools def main(): args = argParser() # Returns a list of Queues for us to loop through kolla = KollaWorker(args['base'], args['type']) kolla.setupWorkingDir() kolla.findDockerfiles() image_pools = kolla.buildQueues(args['namespace'], args['base'] + '-' + args['type'] + '-', args['tag'] ) for pool in image_pools: for x in xrange(args['threads']): WorkerThread(pool).start() # block until queue is empty pool.join() print('============') kolla.cleanup() if __name__ == '__main__': main()

commit_message:
Keep the path when re-registering the template resource

Since Ib0c191db2dccac6d467a9961062424bc1f924c24 we re-register a
template resource in case the global environment is changed. This
is fine but the path to the resource is not maintained. This patch
fixes that by passing the path through to the registration function.

Change-Id: I7a8ec66d0f12a12bb4e44d2eb7efd182d758fea1

commit_message:
console: convert consoles code to use objects framework

blueprint convert-consoles-to-objects

Change-Id: I7d9f8eefc0f3b2ffef87b705c8a75510bb2b91cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/38/165838/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Example Spec - The title of your blueprint ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/convert-consoles-to-objects Make consoles to use objects framework -- The current code of console does not take advantage of the framework objects, instead it provides some types (console/type.py) to handle them. these types do not provide any features to handle versionning, rpc or any kind of methods to make them useful. Problem description =================== The current code does not provide any mechanism to handle versionning also since rpc cannot handle class derrived from the Python object type, we need to handle a dict "connect_info" between process and no way are provided to share data between process. An other problem comes with token, memcached is not a database and cannot quarantee that the expire time will be respected, a token can expires before that limit (eviction). By using the framework objects we can get the opportunity to store the whole state of Console object with a valid token in the database and share the state between process. For instance bug 1425640 needs to know when an user is connected to a particular port and that in different sides; From the compute node, to return the next port defined and not connected - from the proxy to reject new connections on already connected port - from the API to let's user informed no more port are available... Use Cases ---------- Developer can take advantage of using the framework objects when adding a new console or features. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== * Define a new Console object * Convert driver to return Console * Remove using of the dict connect_info * Define schema and api to store console in database * Update code to store Console with valid token in database instead of a cache * Define a periodic task to clean expired Console * Fix bug 1425640 Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- A new Console model needs to be defined with attributes: - host: a string field to handle hostname - port: an int field to handle service number - token: a string field to handle a token or null - access_url: a string field to handle access or null - options: a dict field to handle particular information like usetls, insternal_access_path, mode... No migration are expected, during the upgrade already connected consoles should continue to work until proxy will be restarted. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- In the point of view of tokens we can expect a better security since currenlty tokens are stored in local memory or memcached which both of them do not provide any security layer. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: sahid-ferdjaoui Work Items ---------- * Convert code to use objects framework * Handle tokens with database Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= The current code is already tested by functionnal and unit tests since we do not provide any feature we can consider that the code will be well covered but tests. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

[Ref Arch] Wrong directory

Fixes the wrong direcotry in the Additional task for an existing role section:

/etc/puppet/2014.2-6.1/modules/my_tasks.yaml
--> /etc/puppet/2014.2.2-6.1/modules/my_tasks.yaml

Closes-bug: 1472118

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/64/198964/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This section describes how to install and configure the Compute service on a compute node. The service supports several hypervisors to deploy instances or VMs. For simplicity, this configuration uses the QEMU hypervisor with the KVM extension on compute nodes that support hardware acceleration for virtual machines. On legacy hardware, this configuration uses the generic QEMU hypervisor. You can follow these instructions with minor modifications to horizontally scale your environment with additional compute nodes. .. note:: This section assumes that you are following the instructions in this guide step-by-step to configure the first compute node. If you want to configure additional compute nodes, prepare them in a similar fashion to the first compute node in the example architectures section using the same networking service as your existing environment. For either networking service, follow the NTP configuration and OpenStack packages instructions. For OpenStack Networking (neutron), also follow the OpenStack Networking compute node instructions. For legacy networking (nova-network), also follow the legacy networking compute node instructions. Each additional compute node requires unique IP addresses. .. TODO: add link to each section after migration. To install and configure the Compute hypervisor components ---------------------------------------------------------- Default configuration files vary by distribution. You might need to add these sections and options rather than modifying existing sections and options. Also, an ellipsis (...) in the configuration snippets indicates potential default configuration options that you should retain. .. only:: obs 1. Install the packages: .. code:: console # zypper install openstack-nova-compute genisoimage kvm libvirt .. only:: rdo 1. Install the packages: .. code:: console # yum install openstack-nova-compute sysfsutils .. only:: ubuntu 1. Install the packages: .. code:: console # apt-get install nova-compute sysfsutils 2. Edit the :file:`/etc/nova/nova.conf` file and complete the following actions: * In the ``[DEFAULT]`` and [oslo_messaging_rabbit] sections, configure ``RabbitMQ`` message queue access: .. code:: ini [DEFAULT] ... rpc_backend = rabbit [oslo_messaging_rabbit] ... rabbit_host = controller rabbit_userid = openstack rabbit_password = RABBIT_PASS Replace ``RABBIT_PASS`` with the password you chose for the ``openstack`` account in ``RabbitMQ``. * In the ``[DEFAULT]`` and ``[keystone_authtoken]`` sections, configure Identity service access: .. code:: ini [DEFAULT] ... auth_strategy = keystone [keystone_authtoken] ... auth_uri = http://controller:5000 auth_url = http://controller:35357 auth_plugin = password project_domain_id = default user_domain_id = default project_name = service username = nova password = NOVA_PASS Replace ``NOVA_PASS`` with the password you chose for the ``nova`` user in the Identity service. .. note:: Comment out or remove any other options in the ``[keystone_authtoken]`` section. * In the ``[DEFAULT]`` section, configure the ``my_ip`` option: .. code:: ini [DEFAULT] ... my_ip = MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS Replace ``MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS`` with the IP address of the management network interface on your compute node, typically 10.0.0.31 for the first node in the example architecture. .. TODO: add link to architecture section atfer migration * In the ``[DEFAULT]`` section, enable and configure remote console access: .. code:: ini [DEFAULT] ... vnc_enabled = True vncserver_listen = 0.0.0.0 vncserver_proxyclient_address = MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS novncproxy_base_url = http://controller:6080/vnc_auto.html The server component listens on all IP addresses and the proxy component only listens on the management interface IP address of the compute node. The base URL indicates the location where you can use a web browser to access remote consoles of instances on this compute node. Replace ``MANAGEMENT_INTERFACE_IP_ADDRESS`` with the IP address of the management network interface on your compute node, typically 10.0.0.31 for the first node in the example architecture. .. TODO: add link to architecture section atfer migration .. note:: If the web browser to access remote consoles resides on a host that cannot resolve the ``controller`` hostname, you must replace ``controller`` with the management interface IP address of the controller node. * In the ``[glance]`` section, configure the location of the Image service: .. code:: ini [glance] ... host = controller .. only:: obs * In the ``[oslo_concurrency]`` section, configure the lock path: .. code:: ini [oslo_concurrency] ... lock_path = /var/run/nova .. only:: rdo or ubuntu * In the ``[oslo_concurrency]`` section, configure the lock path: .. code:: ini [oslo_concurrency] ... lock_path = /var/lib/nova/tmp * (Optional) To assist with troubleshooting, enable verbose logging in the ``[DEFAULT]`` section: .. code:: ini [DEFAULT] ... verbose = True .. only:: obs 3. * Ensure the kernel module ``nbd`` is loaded. .. code:: console # modprobe nbd * Ensure the module will be loaded on every boot by adding ``nbd`` in the :file:`/etc/modules-load.d/nbd.conf` file. To finalize installation ------------------------ 1. Determine whether your compute node supports hardware acceleration for virtual machines: .. code:: console $ egrep -c '(vmx|svm)' /proc/cpuinfo If this command returns a value of ``one or greater``, your compute node supports hardware acceleration which typically requires no additional configuration. If this command returns a value of ``zero``, your compute node does not support hardware acceleration and you must configure ``libvirt`` to use QEMU instead of KVM. .. only:: obs or rdo * Edit the ``[libvirt]`` section in the :file:`/etc/nova/nova.conf` file as follows: .. code:: ini [libvirt] ... virt_type = qemu .. only:: ubuntu 1. Edit the ``[libvirt]`` section in the :file:`/etc/nova/nova-compute.conf` file as follows: .. code:: ini [libvirt] ... virt_type = qemu .. only:: obs or rdo 2. Start the Compute service including its dependencies and configure them to start automatically when the system boots: .. code:: console # systemctl enable libvirtd.service openstack-nova-compute.service # systemctl start libvirtd.service openstack-nova-compute.service .. only:: ubuntu 2. Restart the Compute service: .. code:: console # service nova-compute restart 3. By default, the Ubuntu packages create an SQLite database. Because this configuration uses a SQL database server, you can remove the SQLite database file: .. code:: console # rm -f /var/lib/nova/nova.sqlite

commit_message:
Update wsgi.py to support reload from conf on SIGHUP

These changes are taken from the glance wsgi.py from where
heat wsgi.py originated. These changes are to support reload
of the service with new configuration parameters when SIGHUP
is received.

The reload of conf will only work if the server is running
with workers. If workers is 0 then it wont reload.

Co-Authored-By: Tetiana Lashchova <tlashchova@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: I7fd391209591c149fb95136d92dd1d82cfb7a6de
Closes-Bug: #1449807
Closes-Bug: #1276694

commit_message:
Use angular.isUndefined in place of !angular.isDefined

Use the angular.isUndefined function as noted by the eslint rules.

commit_message:
Increase ovsdb timeout.

I've seen several timeouts in the logs for the CI jobs that are
running tempest.  The tests put the VM under heavy load so give things
more time to complete by default before considering it a failure.

Change-Id: Ibc2c64591b2ef26ae481c01b8b4744fb23b4f164
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add support for port admin_state_up

Neutron supports administratively setting the state of a port to up or
down.  Support for this was just merged for OVN and this patch
integrates that support with Neutron.

Change-Id: I4daf4ed752a0e0d2b44fcfc0dc0a86c0e0b50971
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
Closes-bug: #1467971

commit_message:
This documents the use of comments that work between 2.6, 2.7 and 3.4

Comments are not directly handled by PBR, this documents a reasonable working
set of comments that can be used in setup.cfg.

Comments are parsed out over three locations, configparser, which varies rather
significantly between two and three, pkg_resources, and lastly when pip runs.

Change-Id: Iedebc5baca4e21081708971540d6eab89e043f05
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pbr refs/changes/27/193927/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Comments -------- Comments may be used in setup.cfg, however all comments should start with a `#` and may be on a single line, or in line, with at least one white space character immediately preceding the `#`. Semicolons are not a supported comment delimiter. For instance:: [section] # A comment at the start of a dedicated line key = value1 # An in line comment value2 # A comment on a dedicated line value3

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-10 01:08:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance_store/commit/f32eb2e4d3c4b465ed4888a49bda604c3d75e195', 'message': "rbd: clean up unused parents of clones on deletion

In order to make snapshotting ephemeral disks stored in rbd efficient

Since rbd images with snapshots cannot be deleted, nova cannot remove
the original disk in this case. Instead, nova renames the original rbd
image so glance can determine that it is no longer used by
nova. Glance can then delete this rbd image once its snapshots are

commit_message:
rbd: clean up unused parents of clones on deletion

In order to make snapshotting ephemeral disks stored in rbd efficient
and avoid any local disk use, nova will tell glance about an rbd
snapshot's location rather than uploading data.

Since rbd images with snapshots cannot be deleted, nova cannot remove
the original disk in this case. Instead, nova renames the original rbd
image so glance can determine that it is no longer used by
nova. Glance can then delete this rbd image once its snapshots are
deleted.

To effect this, modify the rbd store's backend to recursively delete
any parents that have a special string in their name. This has no
chance of name collision from other openstack use since rbd images are
otherwise only named with uuids.

If an image based on a vm is deleted while the vm is still running,
only delete the parent snapshot, not the whole vm image. Rename
_delete_image() to _cleanup_image(), and add _cleanup_parent() to
determine when deleting the parent is safe.

To allow glance to handle this, it needs write access to the ceph pool
used by nova ephemeral disks.

DocImpact
Partial-Bug: #1346525
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

Change-Id: Ie49cf7f22c4b6c33b27316118e5cfaaad88cce9a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance_store refs/changes/97/127397/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DELETION_MARKER = '_to_be_deleted_by_glance' def _delete_parent(self, parent_pool, parent_name, parent_snap): """Delete the snapshot and image specified, and continue recursively. """ try: self._delete_image(parent_pool, parent_name, parent_snap) except rbd.ImageHasSnapshots: # parent image has other snapshots and will # be deleted when they are deleted. # This image has been deleted though, so # ignore the exception log_msg = _("parent image %(image)s@%(snap)s " "could not be deleted yet") LOG.debug(log_msg, image=parent_name, snap=parent_snap) Delete RBD image and snapshot. Clean up any parent snapshots and images if they are no longer used as well. cleanup_parent = False parent_pool, parent_name, parent_snap = \ image.parent_info() if parent_name is not None: cleanup_parent = DELETION_MARKER in parent_name if cleanup_parent: self._delete_parent(parent_pool, parent_name, parent_snap) try: self._delete_image(target_pool, loc.image, loc.snapshot) except Exception: LOG.debug(_('_delete_image() failed'), exc_info=True) raise
deleted_lines: Delete RBD image and snapshot. self._delete_image(target_pool, loc.image, loc.snapshot)

commit_message:
Add 55572 to the reserved ports list for murano

This change adds 55572 to the reserved ports list for murano. Without
this change, some deployments fail occastionally when port 55572 is in
use.

Change-Id: If62504a5b3b7110d35278fe3654cdbb35dbbe194
Closes-Bug: 1467024
